text: I remember the first time I walked into
a burn unit in Afghanistan and I saw
women who had tried to commit suicide by
setting themselves on fire and the sort
of desperation and the woman's eyes and
I thought how could anyone do this to
themselves my name is Lindsey Dario and
I'm the photographer for the New York
Times have been photographing women's
issues in Afghanistan for the past ten
years as a Western woman it's it's very
hard to conceive of how someone can
douse themselves in gasoline and set
themselves on fire but once you you talk
to Afghan women and you speak to them
and you realize how few options they
have to escape their lives anything
becomes an option when I met girls at UH
she was clinging to her life her son
Juma kept vigil by her side my mother
didn't have any problems I'm still
trying to figure it out days earlier he
and his mother had attended a cousin's
party the next morning cools that uh his
mother set herself on fire I didn't
think she would burn herself
when the Taliban fell from power in
Afghanistan nine years ago it seemed to
indicate a new era of prosperity for
women but here the women speak of
despair
forced marriages abuse and family shame
do you think the situation is better now
than it was under the deliver no dr.
Muhammad Arif Jalali is a senior doctor
at the hospital the main problem is the
economical problem of the people you
know that the forced marriages belong
today canonical problems and some other
rules and some other problems that we
have inside the family and society it's
around the economical problems I met 17
year-old Farzana Nuri nearly two months
after she'd set herself on fire she's
been forced into marriage at age 12 and
said she suffered physical and verbal
abuse from her husband and in-laws she
had a mother rarely Minori invited me
into their home where I asked him what
led to far zhanna's actions I wanted to
die I just wanted to get away from their
words they told their son several times
to divorce me
none of our relatives had gotten a
divorce yet not on my mother's side or
my father's it's a big shame to get a
divorce I thought if I was treated like
this in this house another wouldn't be
any better
so she doused herself with petrol and
set herself on fire day and night I
would just beg God despite these burns
please save her if she dies later I
would have no complaints but not with
these burns please that would leave a
scar of a thousand years on my heart now
she and her mother go to a private
clinic regularly the women I spoke to
offer different explanations for the
drastic suicide attempts some like
Farzana said they'd heard of other women
who had done it for many confinement to
the home limited their suicide options
to items they had at hand like matches
or stove thirteen-year-old najiba had
been married six months when she came to
the hospital with over 85% of her body
burned when I first met her mother I
introduced myself and I asked if I can
photograph her daughter and she just
looked at me and said she's almost
already dead of course she'll die it
doesn't matter take her picture and her
mother just cried day and night and I
spent two days with them and then I
returned one morning and the bed was
empty and the mother was gone
for those women who survived their lives
are often worse than before they burn
themselves their scars make them less
valuable to their husbands and many
women don't undergo the necessary
physical therapy after burns and suffer
muscle contraction Farzana would like to
be able to talk to other women and
persuade them not to burn themselves but
counseling programs are all but unheard
of in Afghanistan at the hospital cools
Ida's condition worsened
[Music]
oh yeah
she don't ya already
I watched quietly as Jimmy ghoul said
goodbye to his mother he had by then
discovered the reason behind her suicide
she had been shamed by relatives for not
bringing a gift to his cousin's party
she had been unable to afford one
